articles.headline: With Imports Banned, Russian Cheese Fills the Need for Brie
articles.snippet: In a bright spot in a largely bleak Russian economy, domestic cheese makers are meeting demand for varieties once imported from Europe.
articles.abstract: In a bright spot in a largely bleak Russian economy, domestic cheese makers are meeting demand for varieties once imported from Europe.
articles.lead_paragraph: GOLOVKOVO-MARINO, Russia — The creamy goat cheese produced at Koza Nostra, a 12-acre farm in this village 75 miles north of Moscow, had largely been a labor of love. The farm had been losing more than $5,000 a month.

articles.headline: Water Pricing in Two Thirsty Cities: In One, Guzzlers Pay More, and Use Less
articles.snippet: Both Fresno, Calif., and Santa Fe, N.M., face dire water shortages, but only one has embraced tiered pricing, where heavy users pay much more per gallon.
articles.abstract: Both Fresno, Calif., and Santa Fe, N.M., face dire water shortages, but only one has embraced tiered pricing, where heavy users pay much more per gallon.
articles.lead_paragraph: FRESNO, Calif. — When residents of this parched California city opened their water bills for April, they got what Mayor Ashley Swearengin called “a shock to the system.”

articles.headline: U.S. Airports Are Better, but Not Best
articles.snippet: While they pale beside the best foreign airports, domestic terminals have improved significantly in the last 25 years, as facilities have expanded and terminals have been modernized.
articles.abstract: While they pale beside the best foreign airports, domestic terminals have improved significantly in the last 25 years, as facilities have expanded and terminals have been modernized.
articles.lead_paragraph: As major airports around the world scramble to brand themselves as luxury entities rather than mere transportation centers, some have adopted a star-ranking system, like hotels. It was inevitable.

articles.headline: Business Travelers Want to Be Left to Their Own Devices
articles.snippet: Smartphones have already transformed vacation planning, but business travelers looking to use Uber, Airbnb and other tech tools find they must take on sometimes unyielding corporate travel policies.
articles.abstract: Smartphones have already transformed vacation planning, but business travelers looking to use Uber, Airbnb and other tech tools find they must take on sometimes unyielding corporate travel policies.
articles.lead_paragraph: Leisure travelers have become used to controlling every step of a trip, from booking a flight or a car to making dinner reservations. Business travelers, less so; there has always been some corporate bean counter looking over their shoulders.

articles.headline: Al Jazeera America Chief Is Ousted After Turmoil
articles.snippet: Ehab Al Shihabi, the former chief, told employees in an email that he would remain as chief operating officer, a title he previously held.
articles.abstract: Ehab Al Shihabi, the former chief, told employees in an email that he would remain as chief operating officer, a title he previously held.
articles.lead_paragraph: Al Jazeera America announced on Wednesday that it was replacing its chief executive, Ehab Al Shihabi, who had held that position since the network’s founding two years ago.

articles.headline: Hillary Clinton Embraces a ‘Super PAC,’ Trying to Erode a Republican Edge
articles.snippet: Hillary Rodham Clinton will begin personally courting donors for a super PAC supporting her candidacy, the first time a Democratic presidential candidate has fully embraced the groups.
articles.abstract: Hillary Rodham Clinton will begin personally courting donors for a super PAC supporting her candidacy, the first time a Democratic presidential candidate has fully embraced the groups.
articles.lead_paragraph: Hillary Rodham Clinton will begin personally courting donors for a “super PAC” supporting her candidacy, the first time a Democratic presidential candidate has fully embraced these independent groups that can accept unlimited checks from big donors and are already playing a major role in the 2016 race.
articles.byline: By Maggie Haberman and Nicholas Confessore

articles.headline: Elton Simpson Eluded U.S. Inquiry Before Texas Shootout
articles.snippet: A lawyer says Elton Simpson, who was killed after opening fire at a Prophet Muhammad cartoon contest, learned how to avoid attention after being the focus of an earlier F.B.I. investigation.
articles.abstract: A lawyer says Elton Simpson, who was killed after opening fire at a Prophet Muhammad cartoon contest, learned how to avoid attention after being the focus of an earlier F.B.I. investigation.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — From 2006 to 2009, long before he would briefly become infamous, Elton Simpson spent many hours sitting in the Kabob Palace, a Phoenix restaurant, earnestly explaining Islam to a Sudanese friend who said he had converted to the faith.
articles.byline: By Scott Shane and Fernanda Santos

articles.headline: Company Creates Bioethics Panel on Trial Drugs
articles.snippet: Johnson & Johnson named the bioethicist Arthur L. Caplan to create a panel to decide on patients’ requests for lifesaving medicines before they are approved.
articles.abstract: Johnson & Johnson named the bioethicist Arthur L. Caplan to create a panel to decide on patients’ requests for lifesaving medicines before they are approved.
articles.lead_paragraph: Johnson & Johnson has appointed a nationally known bioethicist to create a panel that will make decisions about patients’ requests for potentially lifesaving medicine, responding to an emotional debate over whether companies should allow desperately ill people to have access to the drugs before they are approved.

articles.headline: Google, Dominant in Search, Tries Disruptor Role in Wireless and Broadband
articles.snippet: Google’s foray into cellular and broadband is a strategic move aimed at enhancing its position in search and exploiting new profit opportunities.
articles.abstract: Google’s foray into cellular and broadband is a strategic move aimed at enhancing its position in search and exploiting new profit opportunities.

articles.headline: Senate Easily Passes Bill for a Voice on Iran Nuclear Accord
articles.snippet: The Senate voted to give Congress a say in the nuclear agreement with Iran, despite Republican infighting.
articles.abstract: The Senate voted to give Congress a say in the nuclear agreement with Iran, despite Republican infighting.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — A bill that would give Congress a voice in any nuclear agreement between world powers and Iran passed the Senate overwhelmingly on Thursday, a rare bipartisan accord to curb executive authority in an era of expanding presidential power.

articles.headline: N.S.A. Collection of Bulk Call Data Is Ruled Illegal
articles.snippet: The judges ruled that the U.S.A. Patriot Act cannot be legitimately interpreted to permit the systematic gathering of domestic calling records.
articles.abstract: The judges ruled that the U.S.A. Patriot Act cannot be legitimately interpreted to permit the systematic gathering of domestic calling records.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — A federal appeals court in New York ruled on Thursday that the once-secret National Security Agency program that is systematically collecting Americans’ phone records in bulk is illegal. The decision comes as a fight in Congress is intensifying over whether to end and replace the program, or to extend it without changes.
articles.byline: By Charlie Savage and Jonathan Weisman

articles.headline: Marco Rubio’s Immigrant Story, and an Aging Party in Search of a Spark
articles.snippet: Mr. Rubio says his background presents a new twist on the American dream, but some Republicans hope it offers a balm to a party that has been scalded by accusations of prejudice.
articles.abstract: Mr. Rubio says his background presents a new twist on the American dream, but some Republicans hope it offers a balm to a party that has been scalded by accusations of prejudice.
articles.lead_paragraph: ANKENY, Iowa — At a recent ice cream social here, Jim Hallihan liked what he heard from Senator Marco Rubio.
articles.byline: By Jonathan Martin and Ashley Parker
